<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 70, 875, 103]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = x^{d}\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1\), where \(a\) is a positive constant. Find, in terms of \(a\), the coordinates of the centroid of the region enclosed by \(C\), the line \(x = 1\) and the \(x\)-axis. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 100, 650, 119]]<|/det|>
The curves \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\) have polar equations, for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\), as follows:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 127, 556, 148]]<|/det|>
\[C_{1}:r = 2(\mathrm{e}^{\theta} + \mathrm{e}^{-\theta}),\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 148, 546, 168]]<|/det|>
\[C_{2}:r = \mathrm{e}^{2\theta} - \mathrm{e}^{-2\theta}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 175, 475, 193]]<|/det|>
The curves intersect at the point \(P\) where \(\theta = \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 205, 148, 223]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 205, 875, 238]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{e}^{2\alpha} - 2\mathrm{e}^{\alpha} - 1 = 0\). Hence find the exact value of \(\alpha\) and show that the value of \(r\) at \(P\) is \(4\sqrt{2}\).
